When you convert the MD5 hash to a string using `toString(16)`, it will give you a 64-character hexadecimal number. This is because each hexadecimal digit represents 4 bits of data, so you need twice as many characters to represent the same amount of data.

To fix the issue, you need to compare the MD5 hashes in their hexadecimal form, not as strings. Here is the corrected code:

```java
if(md5hashes.equals(encryptedPassWord)) {
    System.out.println("Its exactly the same!");
} else {
    System.out.println("Its not the same!");
}
```

This will correctly compare the MD5 hashes.
